A federal judge in Alaska will reconsider the government's decision against listing the Pacific walrus as threatened Elizabeth Arnold reports from Anchorage
Ten years ago the federal government lifted the polar bear as a threatened species because of declining sea ice conservation groups then petition to list the Pacific walrus for the same reason
But last year the U.S fish and Wildlife Service concluded there's not enough evidence walrus need the ice how well wall or Sarah adapting to a warming climate is at the center of the legal battle now are over there protection
And federal judges agreed to take up that question and challenge brought by the center for biological diversity
Hundreds of thousands of lovers have been coming ashore along Alaska's coast far away from where they feed in the ocean at a critical time in their breeding cycle but government scientists haven't been able to determine yet if less sea ice has directly affected their reproductive rates for NPR News I'm Elizabeth Arnold in Anchorage
